text: to stuff or not to stuff the perennial
Thanksgiving question here are the pros
and cons the pros if you stuff your bird
the stuffing stays moist and it absorbs
all that rich turkey flavor if you don't
stuff the bird the bird cooks a lot
quicker a 20 pound bird will cook an
hour faster if it's unstuffed the
stuffing acts as insulation so it slows
the cooking down of the bird and then
there's the food poisoning issue the
stuffing must reach 165 degrees on an
instant-read thermometer
now if the stuffing is 165 chances are
the breast and the thighs are more like
180 you risk drying out the bird so how
to stuff the turkey this is just your
typical stuffing myth it's my favorite
it's got chestnuts and mushrooms just
put it right in you want to keep the
bird very loosely packed don't tightly
pack it in there you need about I'd say
2 quarts of stuffing for your average 16
pound turkey that's all there is to it
if you're not gonna stuff your bird but
you still want stuffing just bake it in
a casserole dish but don't call it
stuffing because obviously it's not
stuffed into anything if you want to get
Turkey drippings flavor into a dressing
that you're baking on the side I've got
a trick for you however do not serve
this to vegetarians what I've got here
is the flap that was surrounding the
turkey neck when I trimmed it off I
saved it along with whatever other fat I
could gather from the bird chopped it up
and I'm just gonna lay it right on top
as it bakes it's gonna get crispy and
turn into the most delicious golden
little bites and it's gonna flavor
everything underneath it YUM well here
you have it turkey dressing with neck
skin cracklings
